docs.lead_paragraph: A nationwide public employees' strike in France hobbled air and rail service and left schools and post offices operating with reduced staffs today, but it widened rifts in unions about how firmly to resist spending cuts and hiring freezes the French Government says are necessary to get ready for a common European currency in 1999. Militant demonstrators at a Paris rally booed and spat on a moderate union leader who supports parts of a Government plan to eliminate billions of dollars of deficits in the French social security system, which also administers health insurance here.

headline.main: French Strike Slows Planes, Trains and Mail in Protesting Cuts

docs.abstract: Nationwide public employees' strike in France hobbles air and rail service; schools and post offices operate with reduced staff; walkout widens union rifts on how firmly to resist spending cuts and hiring freezes that Government says are necessary to prepare for common European currency in 1999; militants in Paris boo moderate union leader who supports part of plan to cut deficits (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City sued the major tobacco companies yesterday to recoup the billions of dollars that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city has spent to care for people with illnesses caused by smoking. The suit angered one of the city's largest and most influential corporations, Philip Morris, which is the biggest maker of cigarettes in the world.

headline.main: New York City Sues Big Tobacco Companies to Recoup Health Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As an obstetrician-gynecologist for almost 19 years and a medical malpractice attorney for the last 2, I was amazed to read that when Oxford Health Plans expands its insurance coverage to include alternative-medicine coverage, it will not require patients to first obtain approval from their primary-care physicians (news article, Oct. 9) as they must do to see a medical specialist.

headline.main: Oxford's Expanded Health Plan Is Dangerous

docs.lead_paragraph: In a spirited confrontation before the nation's voters, Bob Dole used the final televised Presidential debate last night to attack the ethical and governmental record of President Clinton repeatedly as scandal tainted and undeserving of renewal at the ballot box. ''Many American people have lost their faith in government,'' Mr. Dole said, moving in quickly on the ethics attack in the opening moments of the debate in San Diego in an attempt to reverse Mr. Clinton's formidable leads in popularity polls just 20 days short of the election.

headline.main: DOLE ATTACKS CLINTON'S ETHICS; PRESIDENT PARRIES ON ECONOMY

docs.abstract: Bob Dole repeatedly attacks Pres Clinton's ethical and governmental record in final televised Presidential debate, in San Diego, Calif; says many Americans have lost faith in Government because of scandals on almost daily basis and because of ethical problems in White House that make Administration undeserving of re-election; Clinton bascially ignores accusations, repeatedly invoking nation's economic health and his outlook for further growth in four more years of incumbency; challenges some of Dole's assertions on matters of public policy, particularly contention that state of economy is worst in 20th century; evening is victory of sorts for questioners in audience who press candidates with highly specific questions about issues that generally keep confrontation from becoming acrimonious; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is last night's debate in San Diego between President Clinton and Bob Dole, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS and questions were asked by San Diego area voters selected by the Gallup polling organization. MODERATOR The order for this evening was set by coin toss. We begin now with Senator Dole and his opening statement. Senator Dole. DOLE Thank you very much, Jim.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a classic display of how to run from his party, Representative Phil English puts President Clinton in his television advertisements and tells fellow Republicans that Mr. Clinton's idea of tax deductions for college tuition is a good one. And when he debated his opponent in Pennsylvania's 21st Congressional District a few days ago, Mr. English, a freshman Republican, criticized Bob Dole on tax cuts and tuition vouchers, hailed Mr. Clinton on education, welfare and health insurance, and boasted, ''I broke with my party to fight to raise the minimum wage.''

headline.main: For G.O.P. Freshman, Loyalty Vital in '94 Is a Problem Now
headline.kicker: POLITICS: THE HOUSE -- THE RACE FOR CONGRESS -- Pennsylvania's 21st District

docs.abstract: Article discusses House race in Pennsylvania's 21st District between Republican incumbent Repr Phil English and his Democratic challenger Ron DiNicola; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jane E. Brody's Oct. 9 Personal Health column on chronic fatigue syndrome is misleading. She notes that this syndrome is both physical and psychological, that antidepressants do not cure the illness and that those who suffer are not ''hypochondriacs.'' However, she refers to it as ''a centuries-old disorder'' once known as ''the vapors, neurasthenia'' and suggests that 12 weeks of ''cognitive behavioral therapy'' is useful. This illness has never been fully researched. We do not know whether chronic fatigue syndrome is caused by a virus or a retro-virus, whether it is infectious, or whether it is due to other, unknown causes. We do know that it affects men and children as well as women.

headline.main: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Needs More Research

docs.abstract: Phyllis Chesler/Aviva Rahmani letter disputes Jane Brody's Oct 9 Personal Health column on chronic fatigue syndrome (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The pregnant young women began to vanish from community health clinics in East Los Angeles several weeks ago, scattered by Gov. Pete Wilson's announcement that California would soon cut off prenatal care to illegal immigrants under the new Federal welfare law. Where the women have gone is uncertain. Most seem to have stayed home, assuming that their appointments had been canceled. But where some of the women and their newborn children will turn up, doctors say, is more predictable: in emergency rooms and neonatal intensive-care units. And just as inevitably, the doctors add, their care then will come at a far greater public cost.

headline.main: Pregnant Immigrants Wait Out Policy Storm

docs.abstract: California's plan to cut off prenatal care to illegal immigrants under new Federal welfare law causes pregnant women to vanish from health clinics; public-health officials predict they will eventually turn up in emergency rooms and neonatal intensive-care units, at far greater cost to public; say in addition to humanitarian and clinical considerations, it is extremely prudent financial decision not to let any go without adequate prenatal care; say they may be forced to either carve new resources for illegal immigrants from emaciated county health budgets or do nothing for women, knowing that state and Federal agencies will continue to cover costs of patients' emergency care; lawyers for coalition of civil rights groups file for restraining order, trying to stop cutoff of funds by state on grounds that doing so would violate earlier Federal court ruling and California Constitution; chart; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The pregnant young women began to vanish from community health clinics in East Los Angeles several weeks ago, scattered by Gov. Pete Wilson's announcement that California would soon cut off prenatal care to illegal immigrants under the new Federal...

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST January, on the day before Mary McKilligan was scheduled to have the second phase of breast reconstruction after a mastectomy, her insurance company told her that it would not pay for the operation. Although coverage had been approved several weeks earlier, the company, United Community Health Plan in Latham, N.Y., said it was reversing its decision on the ground that the procedure was cosmetic and therefore not medically necessary. It took eight months of phone calling and letter writing for Ms. McKilligan, her surgeon and her lawyer, they said, to convince the insurance company that the operation was essential to restoring her appearance to what it was before her cancer surgery. Ms. McKilligan, 58, a social worker in Endicott, N.Y., is scheduled to have the reconstructive procedure on Oct. 21.

headline.main: More Insurers Balk on Breast Reconstruction

docs.abstract: Increasing number of insurance companies are denying or restricting coverage for breast reconstruction after cancer surgery; survey by American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons surveys policies; doctors comment (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN I asked Dr. Andrew Weil what to do for hay fever, the plant-loving shaman with the Harvard medical degree suggested eating stinging nettles instead of taking antihistamines, which he said only suppress symptoms and can be toxic. Stinging nettles, scruffy weeds that are sort of the jellyfish of cow pastures, are packed with iron and trace minerals. Picked wild in the spring and steamed, they lose their sting and are as tasty as dandelion greens. You can also buy stinging nettles as a freeze-dried extract in capsules and take two every two to four hours as needed.

headline.main: A Shaman's Tools: Ma Huang And Bloodroot Paste
headline.kicker: ON THE INTERNET WITH: Dr. Andrew Weil
